1.subquestion: What is a quadratic inequality satisfied by all $x$ such that $x^2 - 2x + 2 \le P(x) \le 2x^2 - 4x + 3$?

subanswer.text: Solving the quadratic inequality $x^2 - 2x + 2 \le P(x) \le 2x^2 - 4x + 3$ leads to the interval $[-\frac{1}{2}, \infty)$. The answer is $[-\frac{1}{2}, \infty)$.

ost_step.1: Since $P(x)$ is a quadratic polynomial with real coefficients, it has a minimum value. However, because the minimum value is greater than $-1/2$, the leading coefficient of $P(x)$ must be positive ($a>0$ in the form $ax^2+bx+c$).

direct_answer.text:
